user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of request_completed_callback:
```c
static void
request_completed_callback (void *cls,
                            struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                            void **req_cls,
                            enum MHD_RequestTerminationCode toe)
{
  struct Request *request = *req_cls;
  (void) cls;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) connection;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) toe;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (NULL == request)
    return;
  if (NULL != request->session)
    request->session->rc--;
  if (NULL != request->pp)
    MHD_destroy_post_processor (request->pp);
  free (request);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function request_completed_callback:
struct Request
{

  /**
   * Associated session.
   */
  struct Session *session;

  /**
   * Post processor handling form data (IF this is
   * a POST request).
   */
  struct MHD_PostProcessor *pp;

  /**
   * URL to serve in response to this POST (if this request
   * was a 'POST')
   */
  const char *post_url;

}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The MISRA rule concerns modification of function parameters (the parameter variables themselves must not be modified; objects pointed to by pointer parameters may be). The lines not listed do not modify any parameter variables: the (void) casts only suppress unused-parameter warnings, the NULL check and return (if (NULL == request) return;) only read values, and there are no assignments to the parameter identifiers (cls, connection, req_cls, toe). The reported fragments are the only places where the object obtained via the pointer parameter (req_cls -> *req_cls -> request) or related pointed-to objects are altered (decrementing a member, destroying a post-processor, freeing the object), so they should be investigated for compliance with Rule 17.8. No other lines modify the parameter variables themselves and therefore do not need investigation for this rule.
